{{stack begin}} {{Taxobox | image = Coprinellus impatiens 594720.jpg | image_width = 234px | image_caption = | regnum = [[Fungus|Fungi]] | divisio = [[Basidiomycota]] | classis = [[Agaricomycetes]] | ordo = [[Agaricales]] | familia = [[Psathyrellaceae]] | genus = ''[[Coprinellus]]'' | species = '''''C. impatiens''''' | binomial = ''Coprinellus impatiens'' | binomial_authority = ([[Elias Magnus Fries|Fr.]]) [[J.E.Lange]] (1938) | synonyms_ref = | synonyms = ''Agaricus impatiens'' Fr. (1821)
''Psathyrella impatiens'' (Fr.) [[Claude Casimir Gillet|Gillet]] (1878)
''Coprinarius impatiens'' (Fr.) [[Quél.]] (1886)
''Coprinus impatiens'' (Fr.) Quél. (1888)
''Pseudocoprinus impatiens'' (Fr.) [[Robert Kühner|Kühner]] (1936) }} {{mycomorphbox | name= ''Coprinellus impatiens'' | whichGills= adnexed | capShape= convex | capShape2= flat | hymeniumType= gills | stipeCharacter= bare | ecologicalType= saprotrophic | sporePrintColor= blackish-brown | howEdible= inedible }} {{stack end}} '''''Coprinellus impatiens''''' is a species of [[fungus]] in the [[Psathyrellaceae]] family. First described in 1821, it has been [[classification (biology)|classified]] variously in the genera ''[[Psathyrella]]'', ''Pseudocoprinus'', ''Coprinarius'', and ''[[Coprinus]]'', before [[molecular phylogenetics]] reaffirmed it as a ''[[Coprinellus]]'' species in 2001. The fungus is found in North America and Europe, where the mushrooms grow on the ground in [[deciduous forest]]s. The [[basidiocarp|fruit bodies]] have [[buff (color)|buff]] [[pileus (mycology)|caps]] that are up to {{convert|4|cm|in|abbr=on}} in diameter, held by slender whitish [[stipe (mycology)|stems]] that can be up to {{convert|10|cm|in|abbr=on}} tall. Several other ''[[Coprinopsis]]'' species that resemble ''C. impatiens'' may be distinguished by differences in appearance, [[habit (biology)|habit]], or spore [[morphology (biology)|morphology]]. ==Taxonomy and phylogeny== The species was first described in 1821 as ''Agaricus impatiens'' by Swedish mycologist [[Elias Magnus Fries]] in his ''Systema Mycologicum''. In 1886, [[Lucien Quélet]] transferred the species to ''Coprinarius'' (a defunct genus now [[synonym (biology)|synonymous]] with ''[[Panaeolus]]'') and then to ''[[Coprinus]]'' a couple of years later in his ''Flore Mycologique de la France''. In 1936, [[Robert Kühner]] segregated the genus ''Pseudocoprinus'' from ''Coprinus'', including species that did not have [[wikt:deliquescent|deliquescent]] gills (that is, [[lamella (mycology)|gills]] that "melt" into liquid), and he included ''Coprinus impatiens'' in this generic transfer. He later changed his mind about the [[Taxonomy (biology)|taxonomic]] separation of ''Coprinus'' and ''Pseudocoprinus''. [[Claude Casimir Gillet|Gillet]] transferred the species to ''[[Psathyrella]]'' in 1936. In 1938 [[Jakob Emanuel Lange]] published the new combination ''Coprinellus impatiens''. Despite the taxonomic shuffling, the species was popularly known as ''Coprinus impatiens'' until 2001, when a large-scale [[phylogenetic]] analysis resulted in the splitting of the genus ''Coprinus'' into several smaller genera, and the authors confirmed the validity of the generic placement in ''[[Coprinellus]]''. The [[specific name (botany)|specific epithet]] ''impatiens'' is derived from the [[Latin]] word for "impatient". A 2005 [[phylogenetics]] study proposed that ''C. impatiens'' was sister (closely related on the [[phylogenetic tree]]) to a large ''Psathyrella'' [[cladistics|clade]], and that consequently, the genus ''Coprinellus'' was [[polyphyletic]]. A later (2008) study suggested, however, that these results were due to an artifact of [[Maximum parsimony (phylogenetics)#Taxon sampling|taxon sampling]]—not enough species were analyzed to adequately represent the genetic variation in the genera. The 2008 study demonstrated that ''Coprinellus'', including ''C. impatiens'', was [[monophyletic]], descended from a common ancestor. In their analysis, ''C. impatiens'' was most closely related to ''[[Coprinellus congregatus|C. congregatus]]'', ''[[Coprinellus bisporus|C. bisporus]]'', ''[[Coprinellus callinus|C. callinus]]'', and ''[[Coprinellus heterosetulosus|C. heterosetulosus]]''. ==Description== [[File:Coprinellus impatiens 87451.jpg|thumb|left|The cap surface has deep, narrow, radially arranged grooves.]] The [[pileus (mycology)|cap]] of the [[basidiocarp|fruit bodies]] is initially egg-shaped, then conical to convex before flattening out, reaching diameters between {{convert|1.8|to|4|cm|in|abbr=on}}. It has deep narrow grooves reaching almost as far as the center of the cap. The surface color is a pale [[buff (color)|buff]], [[tawny (color)|tawny]] or cinnamon towards the center, but the color loses intensity when the mushroom is dry. The [[trama (mycology)|flesh]] is whitish, thin, fragile and barely deliquescent (auto-digesting). The [[lamella (mycology)|gills]] are initially [[buff (color)|buff]], then turn grayish brown. They are either free from attachment to the [[stipe (mycology)|stem]], or ''adnexed'', meaning only a small portion of the gill is attached. The stem is whitish, very slender, and more or less equal in width throughout its length, or slightly thicker at the base; its dimensions are {{convert|7|to|10|cm|in|abbr=on}} by {{convert|0.2|to|0.4|cm|in|2|abbr=on}} thick. The stem surface of young specimens are ''pruinose''—appearing to be coated with a minute layer of fine white particles; this eventually is sloughed off, leaving a smooth or silky surface. The odor and taste of the fruit bodies are not distinctive. The gills of this species do not autodigest with age, or barely do so; the fruit bodies tend to become more fragile with age. The [[spore print]] is dark brown. The spores are smooth, [[wikt:ellipsoid|ellipsoid]] or almond-shaped, with a [[germ pore]]; they measure 9–12 by 5–6 [[micrometre|μm]]. The spore-bearing cells, the [[basidia]], are four-spored and tetramorphic (the spores lie on several different levels, and mature at different times). The [[wikt:cheilocystidium|cheilocystidia]] ([[cystidia]] found on the gill edge) are roughly spherical, 20–35 μm broad, or [[wikt:lageniform|lageniform]] (flask-shaped), 36–64 by 10–15 μm, with the apex often rather acute, about 3–5 μm wide. [[Pleurocystidium|Pleurocystidia]] (cystidia found on the gill face) are absent in this species. ==Similar species== [[File:P1050651 Coprinus disseminatus.JPG|thumb|right|A potential lookalike species is ''C. disseminatus''.]] ''[[Coprinellus disseminatus]]'' resembles ''C. impatiens'', but may be distinguished by its slightly larger fruit body, somewhat deliquescent gills, and tendency to fruit in smaller groups on the ground, rather than on or around rotting wood. Also, ''C. disseminatus'' has smaller spores than ''C. impatiens'', typically 6.6–9.7 by 4.1–5.8 μm. ''[[Coprinellus eurysporus|C. eurysporus]]'' is similar to ''C. disseminatus'' but usually grows in groups on fallen branches, and has broader spores that measure 8.3–10.3 by 6.7–8.4 µm. ''[[Coprinellus hiascens|C. hiascens]]'' usually grows in small dense clumps, has narrower spores (typically 9–11 by 4.5–5.5 μm, and produces smaller fruit bodies. ==Habitat and distribution== ''Coprinellus impatiens'' is found in North America and Europe (including Germany, Poland, and the Ukraine) including northern Turkey. In the [[Pacific Northwest]] region of the United States, it is found in [[Oregon]] and [[Idaho]]. Fruit bodies grow solitarily, or rarely in small bundles, on [[forest floor|forest litter]] in [[deciduous forest]]s, especially ones dominated by [[beech]]. ==See also== {{portal|Fungi}} *[[List of
